description: The Associate of Applied Business is an online program developed to meet the needs of working adults looking to enter or advance in a business-related field. Students completing the degree will be equipped with marketable skills necessary for a wide range of business careers and prepared for further education in a bachelor's degree program. The Associate of Applied Business provides a fundamental understanding of business practices through a flexible online format, allowing you to tailor your education to your career goals. This program focuses on developing the essential skills and knowledge needed to succeed in various business roles, from entrepreneurship to management. The online Associate of Applied Business program prepares you for an in-demand career, whether you're looking to start a new job or advance in your current one. You'll gain a foundational understanding of business principles, communication, and decision-making, along with specialized knowledge in your chosen concentration. This program is designed to be highly practical, ensuring you develop skills directly applicable to the workplace. The accounting concentration develops skills for entry-level accounting positions. It includes a strong focus on financial accounting, managerial accounting, and taxation, preparing you for roles in bookkeeping, payroll, and other financial support functions. This concentration provides a solid foundation for those wishing to pursue further studies in accounting or finance.

The entrepreneurship major at Kansas State University prepares students to launch their own business, bring an entrepreneurial mindset to an existing company or organization, or pursue graduate studies. This interdisciplinary major gives students a solid foundation in the entrepreneurial process, from recognizing opportunities and developing innovative solutions to building and managing a successful venture. Students learn critical business skills such as financial management, marketing, and strategy, alongside specialized entrepreneurial knowledge in areas like new venture creation, social entrepreneurship, and corporate innovation. Through hands-on projects, case studies, and interactions with real-world entrepreneurs, students gain practical experience and develop the problem-solving, leadership, and adaptability skills essential for success in today's dynamic business environment.

Hospitality and Tourism Management is one of the fastest growing industries in the world, making it a great career choice. The hospitality and tourism industry provides career paths in lodging, restaurants, tourism, event planning, and club management. The Hospitality and Tourism Management program at K-State is designed to provide students with the knowledge and skills necessary to be successful in this exciting and dynamic industry. Our program is housed within the Department of Kinesiology, which allows us to approach hospitality and tourism from a unique wellness-focused perspective. Students will gain theoretical knowledge and practical experience through coursework, internships, and service-learning opportunities. They will learn about various aspects of the industry, including operations, marketing, finance, human resources, and sustainable practices. The program emphasizes leadership development, critical thinking, and problem-solving skills, preparing graduates for a wide range of management and leadership positions. With a degree in Hospitality and Tourism Management from K-State, you will be well-prepared to make a significant impact in the global hospitality and tourism industry.
Program name: Bachelor of Hospitality and Tourism Management

Concentration name: Community and Commercial Recreation and Sport, Natural Resources and Environmental Interpretation, Therapeutic Recreation
description:
In the park, recreation and leisure studies program, you'll gain the knowledge and skills needed to plan, develop, manage and evaluate parks, recreation, sport and leisure programs for people of all ages, abilities and backgrounds.
You’ll learn how to develop programs and manage facilities in public, nonprofit, commercial and private settings. The curriculum has a common core of courses and allows you to choose from three specializations based on your interests and career goals. Each specialization includes a capstone internship providing an excellent hands-on learning experience that directly translates to employment after graduation.
Accreditation status: The therapeutic recreation specialization is accredited by the Committee on Accreditation of Recreational Therapy Education (CARTE).
Program name: Bachelor of Parks, Recreation and Leisure Studies

description: A Bachelor of Science in Real Estate degree will prepare you for a professional career in the real estate industry, one of the largest industries in the world. The real estate curriculum will provide you with a comprehensive understanding of real estate principles, practices and processes, as well as a solid foundation in finance, economics, appraisal, law, valuation, management, marketing, accounting and statistics. The program provides the necessary background for careers in investment, finance, valuation, property management, brokerage, development and more. The degree requires 120 credit hours of coursework and generally takes four years to complete.

Athletic trainers are health care professionals who collaborate with physicians to provide preventative services, emergency care, clinical diagnosis, therapeutic intervention, and rehabilitation of injuries and medical conditions. The profession of athletic training is recognized by the American Medical Association (AMA), Health Resources Services Administration (HRSA) and the Department of Health and Human Services (HHS) as an allied health care profession. Kansas State University's Athletic Training Program prepares students for a career in this field. Upon graduation, students are eligible to take the Board of Certification (BOC) examination for athletic trainers. The K-State Athletic Training Program is accredited by the Commission on Accreditation of Athletic Training Education (CAATE).
Accreditation status: Accredited by the Commission on Accreditation of Athletic Training Education (CAATE).

description: The undergraduate major in communication sciences and disorders (CSD) at Kansas State University prepares students to become speech-language pathologists and audiologists, or to pursue graduate studies in the field. Speech-language pathologists and audiologists provide services to individuals of all ages who have communication and swallowing disorders. These services include prevention, screening, assessment, diagnosis, treatment, intervention, management, counseling, and follow-up care for communication and swallowing disorders.

The dietetics and clinical nutrition major is a challenging but rewarding course of study for those interested in food, nutrition and human health. This program combines scientific training in basic sciences and nutrition with a strong emphasis on medical nutrition therapy. Graduates of the program are prepared to seek supervised practice (internships) and/or apply to graduate school to complete required steps to become a Registered Dietitian Nutritionist (RDN) and enter a variety of related careers. The Bachelor of Science (BS) in dietetics and clinical nutrition is a program approved by the Accreditation Council for Education in Nutrition and Dietetics (ACEND). This is one of the required steps to become a registered dietitian nutritionist. The curriculum at Kansas State University provides the academic preparation required to apply to supervised practice/internship programs accredited by ACEND. Once supervised practice is completed, graduates are eligible to take the Commission on Dietetic Registration (CDR) credentialing exam to become a registered dietitian nutritionist.
Accreditation status: Approved by the Accreditation Council for Education in Nutrition and Dietetics (ACEND).
Program name: Bachelor of Dietetics and Clinical Nutrition

description:
The bachelor of science in exercise physiology degree program prepares students to work in a variety of health-related fields and pursue graduate study. Students are prepared for careers in clinical, corporate, and university settings, as well as for graduate study in exercise physiology and professional schools such as physical therapy, occupational therapy, and physician assistant.
The curriculum provides a strong scientific background that includes course work in biological sciences, chemistry, physics, and mathematics. Students also complete courses in exercise physiology, human anatomy, human physiology, nutrition, and psychology.
The program emphasizes hands-on learning experiences in the Exercise Physiology Lab, internships, and research opportunities with faculty.

Food science is the discipline in which engineering, biological, and physical sciences are used to study the nature of foods, the causes of deterioration, the principles underlying food processing, and the improvement of foods for the consuming public. Food scientists apply knowledge from many fields of science and engineering to solve practical problems associated with the food system. A food science education can lead to a variety of positions in research and development, quality assurance, regulatory affairs, processing, marketing, and sales within the food industry, government, and academia. The food science program at Kansas State University is designed to prepare students for such careers through its multidisciplinary curriculum and experiential learning opportunities. All students complete an internship experience and can participate in research projects, study abroad, and student organizations. The curriculum meets the requirements for approval by the Institute of Food Technologists (IFT), the scientific society for food science and technology. Students completing the curriculum are considered to have a comprehensive foundation in food science.
Accreditation status: The curriculum meets the requirements for approval by the Institute of Food Technologists (IFT), the scientific society for food science and technology.

Program name: Bachelor of Foods, Nutrition, and Wellness Studies
Bachelor of Health Service Preparatory Studies

description: Medical laboratory scientists are vital members of the health care team. They perform and evaluate medical laboratory tests to provide information for diagnosing, preventing and treating diseases. Their analyses are critical to the detection of cancer, heart attack, diabetes and infectious diseases. Because medical laboratory scientists work with state-of-the-art instrumentation and technology, they must have strong scientific, critical thinking and problem-solving skills. The medical laboratory science program offers classroom, student laboratory and clinical education in all major areas of the clinical laboratory, including clinical chemistry, hematology, immunology, immunohematology, microbiology and molecular diagnostics. You’ll also learn about laboratory operations and management, which include quality control, quality assurance, regulatory compliance and professional standards.
Accreditation status: The Medical Laboratory Science program is accredited by the National Accrediting Agency for Clinical Laboratory Sciences (NAACLS).

description: Prepare to promote the health and well-being of people and communities with a bachelor's degree in public health from Kansas State University. Public health professionals work to prevent disease, prolong life, and promote physical and mental health. Through our program, you'll learn to develop and implement solutions to complex public health challenges across diverse communities. You'll gain skills in epidemiology, biostatistics, environmental health, health promotion, policy, and global health. You'll also learn to analyze health data, conduct research, and communicate effectively to diverse audiences. With a public health degree, you’ll be prepared for various careers in health education, community outreach, epidemiology, health policy, and environmental health. You'll also be prepared for graduate school in public health, medicine, or other health professions. Our public health program is designed to provide you with a comprehensive understanding of public health principles and practices, preparing you to make a positive impact on the health of individuals and populations worldwide. Our curriculum focuses on health disparities, cultural competence, and ethical decision-making, ensuring that you graduate with the knowledge and skills needed to address the most pressing public health challenges of our time. We emphasize hands-on learning, research opportunities, and community engagement, providing you with practical experience and networking opportunities. Join us in shaping a healthier future for all.

The minor in adult development, gerontology, and aging is designed for students interested in learning about adult development and aging processes. The minor explores the multidisciplinary field of gerontology by providing coursework in biology, psychology, sociology, family studies, and health. Students will gain an understanding of the aging process from multiple perspectives. What you'll learn: Understanding of how human development impacts the aging process. Knowledge of the factors influencing health, well-being and quality of life across the adult lifespan. Skills to apply relevant theories and research to solve problems in gerontology. Ability to critically analyze the individual, familial and societal factors that shape the aging experience.
Program name: Minor in Adult Development, Gerontology, and Aging

description: Explore the history, cultures, and contemporary issues of Africa through the African Studies minor at Kansas State University. This interdisciplinary minor allows you to combine your passion for African studies with your major field of study. You’ll develop a broad understanding of the continent, its diverse societies, and its global connections. The minor requires 15 credit hours across at least three different departments, providing a versatile and enriching addition to any degree.

Anthropology is the study of human diversity across time and space. Anthropologists investigate human biology and evolution, linguistic diversity, patterns of culture, and archaeology. An anthropology minor provides students with a broad exposure to the field of anthropology, deepening their understanding of human diversity and providing an interdisciplinary perspective crucial for success in a wide range of careers. The minor is a valuable complement to almost any major, especially those with an international focus, a concern for human diversity, or a focus on health or the environment.

The Minor in Child Development is designed for students who want to deepen their understanding of children's development without majoring in the subject. This minor offers a comprehensive overview of the theoretical frameworks, research methodologies, and practical applications in the field of child development. Students will explore various aspects of child development, including cognitive, social, emotional, and physical growth from conception through adolescence. The curriculum emphasizes an interdisciplinary approach, drawing from psychology, sociology, education, and family studies. Through coursework and experiential learning opportunities, students will gain valuable insights into the factors influencing children's well-being and development, preparing them for careers working with children and families in diverse settings.

The Department of Communication Studies offers a Minor in Communications. This minor is open to all students, regardless of major. The minor requires a minimum of 18 credit hours beyond those taken to fulfill the general education requirements for the student’s degree program.

Program name: Minor in Digital Communication and Media/Multimedia

description: A minor in economics offers students an opportunity to learn the basic principles of economic theory and apply them to a wide variety of policy issues. Students who are successful in the minor will be able to demonstrate competence in economic reasoning, apply economic principles to analyze real-world problems and evaluate various policy alternatives.

American Ethnic Studies is an interdisciplinary field that examines the histories, cultures, social structures, and political experiences of racial and ethnic groups in the United States and globally. The program emphasizes critical analysis of race, ethnicity, indigeneity, and their intersections with other categories of difference such as gender, class, and sexuality. It focuses on the experiences of African Americans, Asian Americans, Indigenous peoples, and Latinas/Latinos, while also engaging with other ethnic groups.
Students develop a deep understanding of the diverse experiences and contributions of ethnic groups, the dynamics of power and inequality, and the struggles for justice and liberation. The curriculum prepares students to critically engage with complex social issues, to analyze various forms of oppression, and to advocate for social change.
Graduates with a B.A. in American Ethnic Studies are equipped with strong analytical, research, and communication skills, which are valuable in a wide range of careers including education, law, public policy, social work, journalism, community organizing, and graduate studies in fields such as ethnic studies, sociology, history, and political science.

Anthropology is the scientific study of humans, past and present, throughout the world. By drawing on four subfields — cultural anthropology, biological anthropology, archaeology and linguistic anthropology — anthropologists explore human diversity in its various forms. K-State's bachelor's degree in anthropology helps students develop skills in critical thinking, research, problem-solving and communication.

The Bachelor of Arts in art is a liberal arts-based degree for students who wish to combine the study of art with other academic areas in the university. It is designed to allow students flexibility in pursuing other majors or minors, or to broaden their intellectual and professional outlooks by taking a variety of courses outside of art. The BA degree in art allows students to select from several areas of concentration as listed below. Each concentration features specific requirements. In addition to studio art coursework, students complete 18 credit hours of art history. The BA in art requires a minimum of 120 credit hours for graduation.
Accreditation status: The Department of Art is an accredited member of the National Association of Schools of Art and Design (NASAD).

Concentration name: Ceramics, Drawing, Graphic Design, Metalsmithing & Jewelry, Painting, Photography, Printmaking, Sculpture
description: The Bachelor of Fine Arts degree in art is a professional degree in studio art for students who wish to pursue careers as exhibiting artists, for those who wish to pursue graduate work in art, or for those who wish to work in related fields such as gallery and museum preparation or conservation. The BFA program focuses on developing high levels of expertise in studio practice, in-depth understanding of theory and criticism, and professional practice knowledge and skills. Students in the BFA program select one or more of the areas of study as their studio concentration, with the option to pursue a secondary area of study. The curriculum for the BFA in art provides for broad exposure to various forms of art making, development of skills in critical thinking, art historical inquiry, and professional preparation. The degree requires a minimum of 120 credit hours.

The Bachelor of Arts in Biochemistry is designed for students who want a broad education in the liberal arts with a strong foundation in biochemistry. This degree allows flexibility for students to combine a biochemistry major with other majors, minors or programs, such as pre-medicine. Students are prepared for a wide variety of career options immediately after graduation or for continued education in graduate or professional schools. Graduates with a B.A. in Biochemistry often pursue careers in biomedical research, biotechnology, pharmaceutical sciences, forensics, scientific writing, and science policy.

The biochemistry curriculum provides a rigorous scientific foundation in chemistry, biology, math and physics. Students learn the structure and function of biological molecules, how they interact with each other and how they carry out the processes of life.
Students are prepared for a variety of careers in biotechnology, health, medicine and agriculture, or for graduate or professional school. The curriculum can be tailored to meet requirements for professional schools, including pre-med, pre-vet, pre-dental and pre-pharmacy programs.

The Biology B.A. program provides a broad foundation in the biological sciences with a particular emphasis on molecular, cellular, and organismal biology, ecology, and evolution. This program is designed for students who want a strong biology background but also desire the flexibility to pursue additional academic interests or pre-professional programs like pre-law or pre-MBA. The curriculum allows students to explore various facets of biology while leaving ample room for electives, minors, or second majors in other disciplines. Graduates are well-prepared for entry-level positions in diverse fields such as environmental consulting, public health, science communication, and laboratory research, or for further graduate studies in biology, education, or other professional fields.

The Bachelor of Science (BS) in Biology program offers an integrated understanding of the biological sciences, with a strong foundation in chemistry, physics, and mathematics. The curriculum is designed to provide students with the knowledge and skills necessary for careers in various biological fields, including biomedical research, environmental science, biotechnology, and health professions. Students will explore topics ranging from molecular and cellular biology to ecology and evolution, developing critical thinking, problem-solving, and laboratory skills essential for scientific inquiry.

Our chemistry degree programs provide an excellent preparation for careers in industry, academia and government, as well as for further study in graduate school or professional schools such as medical, dental or pharmacy school. The Department of Chemistry offers both a Bachelor of Arts (B.A.) and a Bachelor of Science (B.S.) degree program in chemistry.

The B.A. in chemistry provides a solid foundation in the principles of chemistry while allowing students to customize their coursework to include other interests, such as a minor or second major. This degree is popular with students who want to prepare for a career in health care, such as medicine, dentistry or pharmacy.

A bachelor's degree in chemistry provides a strong foundation for a variety of careers in chemistry and related fields, or for further education in graduate school. Our students are prepared to be successful professionals who can address important challenges facing Kansas, the nation and the world. K-State’s chemistry program provides high-quality classroom and laboratory education while emphasizing analytical, quantitative and problem-solving skills, and the ability to communicate scientific results. Students have opportunities to participate in undergraduate research with faculty, complete internships and engage in outreach.

The Bachelor of Science in medical laboratory science is offered by Kansas State University and the University of Nebraska Medical Center College of Allied Health Professions. This 2+2 professional program provides students with an integrated curriculum that builds on a strong foundation in science. The degree combines two years of coursework at K-State and two years of professional coursework at the University of Nebraska Medical Center in Omaha. This program trains students to perform and interpret laboratory tests that detect and monitor disease. Medical laboratory scientists perform tests in all major laboratory disciplines including hematology, microbiology, immunohematology (blood banking), clinical chemistry and molecular biology. Upon graduation, students are eligible to take certification examinations to become nationally certified medical laboratory scientists.
Accreditation status: Accredited by the National Accrediting Agency for Clinical Laboratory Sciences (NAACLS).

description: The Bachelor of Arts in communication studies program will help you learn how to effectively share information with others, influence decision making and build relationships. It is a flexible, highly applicable degree that helps students excel in any career path. The ability to communicate effectively in diverse situations is one of the most highly sought-after skills in today's workforce. K-State's communication studies program focuses on teaching you the foundational knowledge and practical skills that will help you excel as a communicator in any field. The program emphasizes both theoretical and applied aspects of communication and offers courses that cover a wide range of topics, including public speaking, rhetorical theory, interpersonal communication, intercultural communication, organizational communication, political communication, small group communication, and argumentation. You will also develop critical thinking and research skills, preparing you for a variety of careers in fields such as business, education, government, and non-profit organizations. In addition, our program helps prepare students for graduate studies in communication and related fields.

Economics is the study of how people, firms, and governments make decisions when resources are scarce. Economists apply a distinct mode of thinking, grounded in theory and informed by empirical data, to analyze and interpret real-world phenomena ranging from interest rates and unemployment to international trade and financial crises. An undergraduate degree in economics is an excellent preparation for careers in business, law, and public policy, as well as for graduate study in economics and other fields. The Department of Economics offers two undergraduate degrees: a Bachelor of Arts (B.A.) and a Bachelor of Science (B.S.). The B.A. in economics provides a solid foundation in economic theory, policy, and data analysis and has fewer quantitative requirements than the B.S. degree. This allows students to complete a second major or minor in another field (or pursue a general interest) along with their economics degree. The B.A. degree provides excellent preparation for employment in a variety of industries and careers, including banking, finance, consulting, market research, and public policy. It is also suitable for students planning to attend law school or graduate school in fields outside of economics.

The economics major at Kansas State University provides students with a strong theoretical background in the discipline. The economics major is designed for students seeking a rigorous course of study in economics that prepares them for a wide range of career options, including business, law, government, and graduate study in economics. Our graduates are highly analytical and able to identify, analyze, and solve complex problems. This analytical ability, combined with strong quantitative and communication skills, makes our graduates highly marketable in a wide variety of occupations.

As an English major at Kansas State University, you will develop a broad set of skills in critical thinking, research, and communication that are essential for success in any field. Our courses will give you opportunities to read, analyze, and produce texts in a variety of genres and media. You will also develop your understanding of the history of literature, rhetoric, and language, and you will learn how to approach texts from different cultural perspectives.
The English major requires 36 hours of English courses. Because the department offers a wide range of courses, you can customize your program to meet your interests and career goals. While all English majors take a core of required courses (ENGL 287, 290, 399, 501, 502, 580), you have considerable flexibility in selecting other courses to complete the major. Our courses provide an excellent foundation for graduate study in English, as well as for careers in law, business, education, government, journalism, public relations, technical writing, editing, and publishing.

The Bachelor of Arts in Fisheries, Wildlife, and Conservation Biology is a degree offered by the College of Arts and Sciences. Students develop strong foundations in biology, ecology and conservation of plants and animals through a rigorous scientific curriculum and hands-on experiences. The B.A. program provides flexibility to students interested in professional careers in fisheries and wildlife conservation that would also benefit from a second major or minor in another field such as political science, journalism, business or a foreign language. Students who are interested in pursuing a graduate degree in fisheries, wildlife or conservation biology, or a science-related career path, should consider the Bachelor of Science degree option.
Program name: Fisheries, Wildlife, and Conservation Biology, B.A.

Concentration name: Fisheries Science and Management, Wildlife Science and Management, Conservation Biology
description: Students in the Fisheries, Wildlife, and Conservation Biology program prepare for careers in natural resource management, conservation, environmental protection, and scientific research. Our graduates find professional careers with state and federal agencies and private conservation organizations, and many pursue graduate degrees in related disciplines. Our curriculum provides students with a strong background in the foundational sciences and hands-on experience in a variety of laboratory and field settings. The FWCB program is housed in the Division of Biology within the College of Arts and Sciences. Our faculty and staff are experts in the conservation and management of fish, wildlife, and their habitats across Kansas, the Great Plains, and around the world.
Program name: Fisheries, Wildlife, and Conservation Biology, B.S.

description: The Bachelor of Arts in Geography is designed for students with an interest in the social science and humanities aspects of geography. The curriculum focuses on human geography, cultural geography, urban geography, political geography, population geography, economic geography, historical geography, resource management, regional analysis, and geographic information science (GIS). This degree emphasizes understanding the spatial distribution of human activities and their interaction with the environment. Students develop critical thinking skills, analytical techniques, and communication abilities relevant to careers in government, non-profit organizations, international development, education, and private industry. The B.A. program also provides a strong foundation for graduate studies in geography and related fields.

The Bachelor of Science degree in geography emphasizes the scientific study of the earth’s natural and human systems. Students learn how to analyze and interpret spatial data, understand environmental processes, and contribute to sustainable solutions. This degree prepares students for careers in fields such as environmental consulting, urban planning, geographic information systems (GIS), and research. The curriculum provides a strong foundation in physical geography, human geography, and geographic techniques, enabling graduates to address complex local and global challenges.

The Bachelor of Arts (B.A.) in Geology provides students with the fundamental knowledge and skills of a geologist through a flexible curriculum. This degree is ideal for students interested in a broad education in geology and may wish to pursue a second major or an additional specialization. Students develop strong written and oral communication skills, as well as critical thinking and problem-solving abilities.

Geology is the study of the Earth. Geologists investigate processes that form and change the Earth's surface and interior. It is a diverse field covering everything from earthquakes and volcanoes, to mapping, to mining, to understanding Earth's past climate and future. Geologists help us find and manage natural resources such as groundwater, petroleum, and minerals; they characterize and mitigate natural hazards such as floods, landslides, and earthquakes; they investigate environmental problems such as pollution and waste disposal; and they teach us about Earth's history including the evolution of life.
